section.heading: Title.
section.text: This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the "City of Tampa Administration Ordinance."

section.heading: City seal—General restrictions.
section.text: It shall be unlawful for any person to use, display or exhibit in any manner or for any purpose whatsoever the seal of the city or a facsimile thereof, except:

para.text: The officers and employees of the city in connection with city business;
Upon compliance by such person with section 2-3; or
Such person shall have first obtained the written permission of the official and the city council.

annotations.annotation: State Law reference— Wrongful use of city's name, F.S. § 817.17.

section.heading: Same—Cigar manufacturers granted use under enumerated conditions.
section.text: Any manufacturer of cigars made within the corporate limits of the city shall have and is hereby granted the privilege, which shall continue for so long as this section shall remain in effect and as such manufacturer shall comply with the terms and conditions hereof, of using, displaying or exhibiting upon the container, package or wrapper of such cigars a facsimile of the official and corporate seal of the city upon compliance by the manufacturer with the following:

para.text: The manufacturer shall be the holder of a current and valid city occupational license tax receipt for the manufacture of the cigars;
The container, package, or wrapper shall bear in a prominent place and bold letters the words "Made in Tampa" or words of similar import; and
The manufacturer shall first file with the city clerk the affidavit of the proprietor thereof, or, if a corporation, the affidavit of the president thereof, showing the following:
The name of the manufacturer;
The name of each brand of cigars for which the facsimile is to be used, displayed or exhibited; and
The street address of the factory in which each brand of cigars is manufactured.

container.heading: CITY CLERK
container.annotation: 2 Charter reference— City clerk, Art. III.
Cross reference— Code of ethics for officials and employees, § 2-326 et seq.

section.heading: Duties generally.
section.text: It shall be the duty of the city clerk to:

para.text: Record every official meeting of the city council;
Be responsible for the recording, filing, indexing and safekeeping of all proceedings of the city council;
Publish legal notices unless otherwise provided;

Have charge of and file all ordinances, resolutions, executive orders, contracts, deeds, oaths of office, and all other documents of which he may be made custodian by law, or as may come into his possession as city clerk;
Be the custodian of the official city seal;
Perform all such other duties as may be designated from time to time by ordinance.
The official is hereby authorized and empowered to appoint from time to time one (1) or more deputy city clerks, who shall hold office at the pleasure of the official.

Each deputy city clerk shall, in the event of the death, disqualification, inability to act or absence from the city of the city clerk, have and may exercise all the powers and functions and perform all of the duties now or which may be hereafter vested in or imposed upon the city clerk.
Each deputy city clerk so appointed shall take the oath as prescribed by law.

container.heading: ARCHIVES AND RECORDS SERVICE
container.annotation: 3 State Law reference— Public records, F.S. Ch. 119; mandate to establish a program for disposal of records, F.S. § 119.01(2); public meetings and records, F.S. § 286.011.

section.heading: Short title; purpose.
section.text: This division shall be known and may be cited as the "City of Tampa Archives and Records Service." The declared purpose of these sections is to provide for the proper and efficient management of the public records of the city and for the operation of a central repository for the city's permanently valuable records.

section.heading: Definitions.
section.text: The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:

Archival records means those records, manuscripts and other records which document the origin and history of the government of the city and the development of its agencies which are worthy of permanent preservation and special administration because of the importance of the information they contain.
City clerk means the city clerk of the City of Tampa, Florida, or his duly designated representative.
Inactive records means those records no longer required in active office areas but which require further retention due to legal, fiscal, administrative or archival value.

Maintenance of public records means the creation, maintenance, protection, use and disposition of all public records of the city, including the establishment and maintenance of a system of filing and indexing public records.

Public records means all documents, papers, letters, maps, books, tapes, photographs, films, sound recordings or other materials, regardless of physical form or characteristics, made or received pursuant to law or ordinance or in connection with the transaction of official business by any officer or employee of the city; however, public records shall not be construed to mean those public records which are deemed by law to be confidential or which are prohibited from being inspected by the public or which shall be exempt from the provisions of this division or from the provisions of the state Public Records Act.

annotations.annotation: Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.

section.heading: Ownership of public records.
section.text: All public records shall be the property of the city, and, in this regard, such records shall be delivered by outgoing officials and employees to their successors.

Inactive records shall be transferred to the city records center. When such records are determined archival and accepted, the archives shall be considered the legal custodial site and the city clerk shall have disposal authority.

annotations.annotation: State Law reference— Disposition of records at end of official's term, F.S. § 119.05.

section.heading: Duties of officers and employees.
section.text: It shall be the duty of each officer and employee of the city to protect, preserve, store, transfer, destroy or otherwise dispose of, use and manage public records only in accordance with applicable federal, state or local law, or such rules as may be promulgated or approved by the city clerk.

section.heading: Duties of city clerk.
section.text: It shall be the responsibility of the city clerk to administer the City of Tampa Archives and Records Service. In this regard the city clerk, among all other things that may be required for the proper and efficient management of the public records of the city, shall:

para.text: Develop and circulate such rules and regulations as may be necessary and proper to implement and maintain the records management program;
Provide and maintain a city records center to house and preserve inactive records prior to disposition;
Advise and assist city departments in the preparation of records inventory and destruction schedules;
Approve destruction schedules before disposition of the public records;
Organize and administer the City of Tampa Archives:
Identify and ensure the preservation of city archival records, requiring their transfer to the archives if deemed necessary.
Provide for and direct a city archivist/records manager who shall ensure the sound management of archival records and their availability for research.
Promote educational and research use of the city archives by individuals, organizations in the community, and other researchers.
Accept from any person any papers, books, records and similar materials which in the judgment of the department warrant preservation in the city archives.
Appoint an advisory committee to promote the archives, provide professional assistance and foster a cooperative approach to the historical resources of the Tampa area.
Provide microfilming services for public records pursuant to rules promulgated by the city clerk for the centralization of such services;

Conduct, as the city clerk deems necessary, such surveys, studies and investigations as will assist in promoting a proper and efficient records management program for the city, including information retrieval systems.

annotations.annotation: State Law reference— Custodian designated, F.S. § 119.021.

para.text: Departments shall create and maintain all records with adequate and proper documentation of the organization, together with the functions, policies, decisions, procedures, and essential transactions, of the department.

Departments, with the advice of the city clerk, shall establish and maintain an active, continuing program for the economical and efficient management of the records of each respective department. Such program shall, among other things, provide for:
Effective controls over the creation, maintenance and use of records in the conduct of current business;
Cooperation with the city clerk in applying standards, procedures and techniques designed to improve the management of records;
Promotion of the maintenance and security of records deemed appropriate for preservation;
Segregation and disposal of records of temporary value in accordance with established retention schedules.

Those public records which are not required in the current operation of the office where they are made or kept, and all public records which can properly be abolished or discontinued, shall be transferred to the city records center or archives.
Each department of the city shall designate a representative to coordinate the management of records in that department. The representative shall:
Coordinate all records management activities and functions within the department and with the city clerk;

With the advice and assistance of the city clerk, inventory or manage the inventory of all public records for disposition scheduling and transfer action in accordance with procedures prescribed by law or rule promulgated by the city clerk.
Consult with any other personnel responsible for creation or maintenance of specific records within his department regarding records retention and transfer recommendations;

Analyze records inventory data, examine and compare division or unit inventories for duplication of records, and recommend to the city records officer minimal retentions for all copies commensurate with legal, financial and administrative needs.
Review established records retention schedules at least annually to ensure that they are complete and current.

The city clerk shall be responsible for administering the archives and records service program in compliance with state laws and the regulations of appropriate state agencies relating to the scheduling and disposition of public records of the city.

The city clerk shall be responsible for the systematic destruction of the city's public records when such records have met their approved retention period and destruction has been authorized by the appropriate department head and state agency. The method of destruction will satisfy state and city requirements.

The city clerk shall keep an index of all scheduled records which have been filed with or submitted to the appropriate state agency and shall further prepare and keep disposal certificates in accordance with state law or regulations on destroyed records.
The city clerk is authorized to promulgate rules and regulations not inconsistent with this section, as may be necessary and proper to implement the objectives hereof.

container.heading: DEPARTMENT OF REVENUE AND FINANCE
container.annotation: 5 Charter reference— Department of revenue and finance, § 5.01(b).

section.heading: Annual inventory.
section.text: During each fiscal year the director of finance shall cause to be conducted a physical count of all inventory and property. The method for conducting the count will be determined by the director of finance and will comply with accepted accounting procedures. A full and detailed list of all property will be prepared and submitted to the official. Upon receiving the official's approval, a copy will be filed with the city clerk.

section.heading: Keeping regular books of accounts.
section.text: In addition to the duties prescribed by the Charter, the director of finance shall keep regular books of accounts of the city in which he shall enter all indebtedness of the city, and which shall at all times show the precise financial condition of the city, the amounts of bonds, orders, certificates, warrants or other evidence of outstanding indebtedness and the redemption of the same when redeemed.

section.heading: Countersign all evidences of indebtedness of city.
section.text: The director of finance shall countersign all bonds, certificates or other evidences of indebtedness of the city, and no such bond, certificate or other evidence of indebtedness shall be valid unless countersigned by him.

section.heading: Travel expense forms and regulations.
section.text: The director of finance shall provide forms for travel requests, expenses, reimbursements and mileage allowances, and prescribe such regulations as are necessary.

para.text: The city shall make all rules and regulations to govern reports and accounts by all persons remitting revenues to the city for the purpose of enabling the city to ascertain whether or not such revenues are being remitted to the city in an appropriate manner as required by this Code or applicable law.

The city is further given power to investigate or cause to be investigated, under its authority, all cases involving the remittance of revenues to the city as provided in subsection (a) of this section to determine from such investigation whether or not such revenues are remitted as required by this Code or applicable law, and the determination of the city in any case shall be prima facie valid and authentic in all courts in this state.

No less then forty-five (45) days before the expiration of each fiscal year, the mayor shall submit a supplemental revenue and expenditure document concurrently with the submission of the annual budget for the next fiscal year.

The content and degree of detail of the supplemental revenue and expenditure document shall be consistent with the past practice and custom of the mayor and the council and shall contain sufficient detail to afford the city council the opportunity to make an informed decision with respect to income and expenditures for the fiscal year covered by the annual budget that is under review for approval by the city council.

Proposed changes in the content of the supplemental revenue and expenditure document that substantially deviate from the past practice and custom of the mayor and the council shall be approved by resolution of the city council prior to submission of the supplemental revenue and expenditure document pursuant to subsection (a), herein.

container.heading: DEPARTMENT OF CONVENTION FACILITIES
container.annotation: 6 Cross reference— Alcoholic beverages in convention centers, § 3-146.

section.heading: Established; jurisdiction.
section.text: There is hereby established a department of convention facilities which shall have jurisdiction and cognizance over all activities relating to conventions and convention facilities in the city.

section.heading: Director.
section.text: The head of the department of convention facilities shall be called the director of convention facilities. The director shall be appointed and confirmed as is provided in section 6.03 of the Charter. The director shall be responsible to the official for the management and operation of the department and shall keep all records and accounts of the department. Further, he shall have such other powers and duties as are prescribed by ordinance.

section.heading: Functions.
section.text: The department of convention facilities shall have cognizance over:

para.text: All buildings, equipment and facilities provided for convention activities in the city, including the supervision and control of the boat docking facilities adjacent to the Hills borough River beginning at the park adjacent to the Tampa Convention Center circular drive on the east side of the river along the Tampa Convention Center River Walk and ending at Platt Street in the city;

All activities relating to any convention center and all matters relating to entertainment, securing of conventions, marketing, promotions, management, scheduling, conduct, preservation, and rules and regulations for the use of any such facilities;
All publicity relating to convention matters;
Such other activities of a public nature as may be designated by the official.

section.heading: Sureties of persons dealing with city to be licensed by state; premium of bonds of officials to be paid by city.
section.text: Whenever it may be necessary for any person to give or furnish to the city a bond for any purpose with surety, such surety shall be a surety or indemnity company licensed and authorized to do business with this state. Whenever such bond is an official bond of an officer or employee required by the Charter, the premium for such bond shall be paid by the city.

annotations.annotation: Charter reference— Bonds for officers and employees, § 6.04.

para.text: There shall be each year, except during a year in which the records of the city are audited by the state auditor general, a postaudit of all the books, records, inventories and reports of the director of finance, and of all officers and employees who receive and/or disburse public funds, conducted and performed by an independent certified public accountant appointed by the official with the approval of the city council. The term "independent certified public accountant" shall mean a person certified and licensed as a certified public accountant, wherein neither the person, firm, or corporation nor any member, officer, agent, or employee thereof shall have, during the period of his professional engagement or at the date of his report or during the period covered by the financial statement, any relationship with the city as officer, employee or accountant, in any manner over which the certified public accountant has performed accounting services. For purposes of this section, "accounting services" shall mean preparing financial statements, including adjusting and closing the general books. Nothing contained in this section shall preclude the certified public accountant from providing the city, for a fee or otherwise, with an accounting system formulation designed to improve the city's accounting capability. For purposes of this section, the term "accounting system formulation" shall mean developing, designing and recommending to management plans, programs, procedures and methodologies to be used by management in carrying out its duties and responsibilities in a more effective and efficient way.

Notwithstanding any provisions contained in this section, if federal auditing standards require that the independent public accountant have no business relationship with the city except for the performance of audits, then those federal programs covered by such regulations shall be audited in conformity with the appropriate federal regulations.

It shall be unlawful for any person to fail to comply with or to violate the provisions of this section. The failure of the official or the city council to cause the audit to be made as provided in this section shall be grounds for recall of such officers.

annotations.annotation: State Law reference— Financial management and reporting requirements, F.S. §§ 166.241(1), 218.30 et seq.

section.heading: Authority of city attorney and risk manager to dispose of claims against city.

para.text: The city attorney and/or his designee is hereby authorized to deny claims against the city without further approval of the city council when in his opinion:
It is in the best interest of the city to do so; and
A reasonable investigation has revealed that the claim is without merit.
The city attorney and/or his designee is hereby authorized to settle or pay claims against the city without further approval of the city council when, in his opinion:
It is in the best interest of the city to do so;
There is no substantial issue of liability involved; and
The amount is no greater than twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00).
The risk manager of the city and/or his designee is hereby authorized to settle or pay claims against the city without further approval of the city council when, in his opinion:
It is in the best interest of the city to do so;
There is no substantial issue of liability involved; and
The amount is no greater than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00).

container.annotation: 9 Charter reference— Depositories and disbursements, § 7.09.
State Law reference— Municipal investments, F.S. § 166.261.

section.heading: Qualified institutions; duty of director of finance.
section.text: Only banks or savings associations meeting all of the requirements of the Florida Security for Public Deposits Act, F.S. Ch. 280, and designated by the state treasurer as a qualified public depository may be designated a city depository. The director of finance shall be responsible for ensuring the status of those banks and savings associations designated as city depositories, and, once this status is verified, he may deposit city funds without the formal requirement of a depository agreement. He shall require each depository bank receiving any money as provided in this section to provide him with a safekeeping receipt for a certificate of deposit or securities or validated receipt for such funds which he shall carefully preserve and keep and make available for inspection as provided by law.

container.heading: PURCHASES AND CONTRACTS
container.annotation: 10 Editor's note— Ord. No. 95-109, §§ 1-5, adopted May 25, 1995, amended Div. 3 to read as herein set out. See the Code Comparative Table.

section.heading: Approval, bidding for certain purchases and various contracts.

para.text: All purchases by the city and all contracts for the furnishing to the city of supplies, printing, materials, equipment, machinery, appliances and other commodities, and services, including the repair of heavy equipment of the city (except those services which are professional, or highly technical or specialized), requiring an expenditure of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) or more shall be first approved by the city council upon recommendation of the mayor and made only upon a formal competitive bidding basis, which may include on-line procurements, after due advertisement for bids or qualifications for on-line procurement, as the case may be, as shall be prescribed by the city council.
The director of the purchasing department is authorized to make purchases requiring expenditures of less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) without the approval of the city council.

The director of the purchasing department is bound and governed by the competitive bidding procedures as provided for in the City of Tampa's Purchasing Procedures Manual, 1992, as amended, on file in the office of the city clerk. The terms and conditions of said manual are hereby adopted by reference and shall have the full force and effect of law.

In the event of set-asides regarding the award of contracts for city purchases, awards and contracts to women and minority business enterprises (W/MBEs) as authorized by Chapter 26.5 of the City of Tampa Code, the competitive bidding requirement hereinabove set out shall be limited to the current list of certified W/MBEs.

section.heading: Approval, bidding for public improvement contracts.
section.text: Public improvement contracts, being all contracts for the furnishing to the city of labor and materials for the construction, reconstruction, alteration, repair and/or maintenance of public improvements shall be handled by the operating department except that smaller projects estimated to cost less then one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) may be handled by the director of purchasing subject to the competitive bidding procedures set forth in the manual described in section 2-276 above.

All public improvement contracts requiring an expenditure of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) or more shall be handled by the operating departments and shall be made only upon a competitive bid basis after plans and specifications have been prepared, are on file in the operating departments and, upon recommendation of the mayor, have been approved by the city council.

section.heading: Manner and form of advertisements for bids and requests for qualifications for on-line procurements for certain purchases and contracts.

para.text: The following forms are prescribed for use by the purchasing department for the purpose of securing due advertisement for bids or requests for qualifications for on-line procurements, pursuant to section 2-276, on all purchases by the city of supplies, printing, materials, equipment, machinery, appliances, and other commodities and services, including all contracts for the repair of heavy equipment, which require an expenditure of city funds of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) or more:

Sealed bids for the furnishing of _______ will be received by the Director of Purchasing, City of Tampa, in her office until _______ a.m., _______, (Date), then and thereafter to be publicly opened and read. Bid documents are available at the Purchasing Department.
Director: _______

Sealed letters of interest and qualifications for the furnishing of _______ will be received by the Director of Purchasing, City of Tampa, in her office until _______ a.m., _______, (Date), then and thereafter to be publicly opened and read. Bid documents are available at the Purchasing Department.
Director: _______

The form "invitation to bid" or "request for qualifications," as the case may be, provided for in subsection (a) of this section shall be published one (1) time at least five (5) days prior to the opening of bids or letters of interest and qualifications, as the case may be, in a newspaper of general circulation published in the city.

For all items for which funds are budgeted, the director of purchasing is authorized and empowered to advertise for bids or requests for qualifications for on-line procurements in accordance with the provisions of this section without further, additional or prior approval of the city council; however, the director shall attach and submit to the council along with the requested approval of the lowest responsible bid, the following:

text.em: In the case of an "invitation to bid:"

para.text: Copy of the newspaper advertisement "invitation to bid" showing the date that the advertisement was published and the name of the newspaper;
A list of all bidders; and
A tabulation of all bids.

text.em: In the case of a "request for qualifications for on-line procurement:"

para.text: Copy of the newspaper advertisement "request for qualifications for on-line procurement" showing the date that the advertisement was published and the name of the newspaper;
A list of all respondents to the "request for qualifications for on-line procurement;" and
A tabulation of all price quotes submitted during the on-line procurement.

Nothing in this section shall be construed as applying or relating to advertisements for bids or requests for qualifications for on-line procurements on projects, contracts, or purchases which, in whole or in part, involve the use of federal funds or bond money or which come under the city's women and minority business enterprises ordinance.

section.heading: Approval of valid emergencies; competitive bidding and bond exemptions.
section.text: In case of valid emergencies for purchases or contracts as delineated in sections 2-276 and 2-277, the requirements of competitive bidding and the provision of an appropriate bond may be waived. The furnishing of labor and materials requiring an expenditure of less than fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) and of labor only regardless of the expenditure amount by be exempted from the requirement of an appropriate bond for public improvements and the maintenance of public facilities.

section.heading: Certain work orders to be approved by city council.
section.text: Notwithstanding any other provisions of the City of Tampa Code, no work orders for the provision of professional services as defined in F.S. § 287.055, exceeding one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) to any single provider or for any project shall be allowed or permitted with the city unless and until such work order shall first be approved by resolution passed by the city council.

section.heading: On-line vendor (bidder) system.
section.text: The purchasing department maintains an on-line bidder system in the mainframe computer for all vendors (bidders) desiring to do business with the City of Tampa. To be placed in the computer system, vendors (bidders) must submit a completed vendor application to the purchasing department.

para.text: Purpose.This section shall govern any protest made by any actual bidder or proposer, who is allegedly aggrieved in connection with the issuance of a bid solicitation, proposal solicitation or pending award of any contract in any competitive process utilized by the City of Tampa for procurements of supplies, materials or services and construction of public improvements and has standing to protest under Florida law. Protests not complying with the provisions of this section shall not be reviewed.

Time for filing a protest. Protests shall only be accepted within the timeframes as stated herein. Any protest received outside of these timeframes shall not be considered. Protests shall be filed with the director of the soliciting department, either the director of purchasing or designee, or the director of contract administration or designee, which shall be specified in the solicitation by the city. For all solicitations with estimated expenditures of twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) or more, protests must be filed with the director of the soliciting department in writing within five (5) city business days after the city posts notice of intent to award by means which shall be specified in the solicitation by the city. For solicitations with estimated expenditures of less than twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00), the protesting party shall bear the responsibility of ascertaining whether the city has made a decision of intent to award and of filing any protest within five (5) city business days of said decision. All protests must be received by the director of the soliciting department or designee by 4:30 p.m. on the date as specified above. Protests received after this timeframe will not be considered. It is the responsibility of the bidder(s) or proposer(s) to review posted notices from the city in order to file a protest in a timely manner. Standing to protest is limited to parties that have submitted bids or proposals.

Required form of protest. All protests shall be in writing and state that the bidder or proposer is submitting a formal notice of protest. Failure to follow the required form of protest shall be just cause for rejection of the protest. Delivery by certified or registered mail, email, fax (original copy sent immediately following), or hand delivered to the director of the soliciting department or designee is acceptable. Protests shall be date and time stamped upon receipt and if hand-delivered a receipt shall be issued to the protesting party stating the date and time the protest was filed. A party protesting may be represented by legal counsel at its own expense. A protesting party shall bear all costs of the protest other than salary and personnel costs of city employees. No documentation may be submitted after filing of the protest. The notice of protest shall include the following information:
The name, postal and email address, telephone and facsimile numbers of the party protesting;
The city bid or proposal number and title;

A concise statement indicating the grounds and evidence, including facts, rules, regulations, statutes and constitutional provisions, the factual and legal basis, upon which the protest is based, with inclusion of all supporting documentation. Grounds not specifically stated in writing shall be waived;
A statement of the specific ruling or relief requested; and
Signature by an authorized agent of the party protesting.

Rights of other interested parties to protest procedures. Interested parties, other than the protesting party and the city, which will be directly affected by the resolution of the protest, and have legal standing, shall have the right to intervene in such protest proceeding by providing written documentation related to the protested solicitation. Said interested parties shall bear the responsibility of determining whether a protest has been filed with the city. Any documentation submitted by these interested parties must be filed with the director of the soliciting department within five (5) city business days of receipt of the protest by the city. Said documentation must be received by the director of the soliciting department or designee by 4:30 p.m. on the date as specified above. Documentation received after this timeframe will not be considered. Delivery by certified or registered mail, email, fax (original copy sent immediately following), or hand delivered to the director of the soliciting department or designee is acceptable. Said documentation shall be date and time stamped upon receipt and if hand-delivered a receipt shall be issued to the party stating the date and time the said documentation was filed. Any said interested party may be represented by legal counsel at its own expense. Any said interested party shall bear all costs of its submissions to the city. The notice of protest shall be made available to said interested parties upon a written request for same. Documentation shall include the following information:
The name, postal and email address, telephone and facsimile numbers of the party intervening;
The city bid or proposal number and title;

A concise statement indicating the grounds and evidence, including facts, rules, regulations, statutes and constitutional provisions, upon which the intervention is based, with inclusion of all supporting documentation;
A statement of the specific ruling or relief requested;
Signature by an authorized agent of the interested party.

When a notice of protest is received, the director of the soliciting department shall serve as a review officer to evaluate the submissions by interested parties, including the notice of protest, the documentation from any other interested party, and documentation related to the protested solicitation provided to the director of the soliciting department from that department.
The decision by the review officer will be based on written submissions only.

The review officer shall issue a written decision to uphold or reject the protest, containing the basis of the decision within fifteen (15) city business days after submission of documentation by interested parties has been filed with the director of the soliciting department.
If additional time is required to review the protest, interested parties shall be notified. In no event shall the additional time exceed more than ten (10) additional city business days.

If a protest is denied, the protesting party may file a request for appeal with the director of the soliciting department. The appeal shall be submitted in writing and sent by certified or registered mail, or hand-delivered to the director of the soliciting department or designee. Appeals will be date and time stamped upon receipt and if hand-delivered, a receipt will be issued to the appealing party stating the date and time the appeal was filed.

The appeal must be filed with the director of the soliciting department within three (3) city business days of the issuance of the decision of the review officer. Any appeal received outside of this timeframe will not be considered.

At the filing of the appeal, the appealing party shall post with the director of the soliciting department, a security in the form of a bond (in a form, and with such terms, approved by the director) payable to the City of Tampa in an amount equal to ten (10) percent of the total bid or proposal amount, or the value of the solicitation as estimated by the city prior to a solicitation's opening date, or twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00), whichever is less. The surety issuing the bond must be authorized to do business in the State of Florida and be in compliance with the Florida Insurance Code. Any bond submitted shall have a duly executed power of attorney attached. In lieu of a bond, the city may accept an irrevocable letter of credit, cashier's or certified check, or money order in the above amount (in a form, and with such terms as approved by the director). Noncompliance with this requirement, in whole or in part, shall be deemed to be a waiver by the protesting party of the right to appeal. Said security shall be designated and held for the payment of any costs that may be levied against the appealing party. If the appeal is successful, the posted security shall be refunded in full.
The request for appeal must include the following:
The name, postal and email address, telephone and facsimile numbers of the party appealing;
The city bid or proposal number and title;

A concise statement indicating the grounds and evidence, including facts, rules, regulations, statutes and constitutional provisions, the factual and legal basis, upon which the protest is based, with inclusion of all supporting documentation. New grounds or evidence not previously set forth in the written protest that reasonably could have been raised when the protest was initially submitted will not be considered;
A statement of the specific ruling or relief requested; and
Signature by an authorized agent of the party appealing.
Notice of hearing date and hearing.

Upon filing of a timely request for appeal, the director of the soliciting department shall notify the city attorney and forward the request for appeal within three (3) days of receipt of the request to the procurement appeals hearing officer so designated by the city attorney pursuant to subsection (j).

The procurement appeals hearing officer shall set a hearing date not more than ten (10) city business days from the date of receipt of the request for appeal from the director of the soliciting department. The procurement appeals hearing officer shall cause notice of the hearing date, time and location to be served upon all parties who will be directly affected by the resolution of the appeal by certified mail, return receipt requested. The procurement appeals hearing officer may extend the deadline for completion of the hearing upon written petition for good cause shown; however, such extension shall not exceed an additional five (5) city business days.

The procurement appeals hearing officer shall conduct a de novo hearing. The burden of proof shall rest with the appealing party. The standard of proof shall be whether the decision by the review officer was clearly erroneous, arbitrary or capricious, fraudulent, or otherwise without basis in fact or law. Any decision shall be based on substantial competent evidence. The hearing shall begin with a statement by the procurement appeals hearing officer of the rules and procedures of the hearing, followed by a general statement of the facts by the director of the soliciting department. Representatives of the appealing party, limited to its owners, officers, employees and/or legal counsel, will then be required to present its case. Those parties, other than the appealing party, who have standing and will be directly affected by the resolution of the appeal, limited to its owners, officers, employees and/or legal counsel, will be given an opportunity to be heard and to present information, which will be followed by a statement and presentation of information from the director of the soliciting department and its legal counsel. Party presentations shall be limited to two (2) hours per party. All examinations and cross-examinations shall be conducted by the procurement appeals hearing officer. All parties shall be provided a fair and impartial hearing. Strict rules of evidence shall not apply. Hearsay evidence may be admissible, and used to supplement or explain other evidence, but shall not be sufficient in itself to support a finding unless it would be admissible over objections in civil actions.

Decision and notice of decision. The procurement appeals hearing officer shall, within seven (7) days of the hearing, make a written decision on the appeal, which decision shall affirm or deny the decision by the review officer. The decision shall be sent to all parties by registered mail and shall set forth the reasons for the decision.

Recovery of costs by the city. If at the appeals hearing the city prevails, the procurement appeals hearing officer shall assess against the appealing party reasonable costs incurred by the city in convening the hearing, including the costs and fees for the procurement appeals hearing officer. Such costs of the hearing shall be paid to the city within five (5) business days after receipt by the appealing party of the decision upholding the decision of the review officer. Any costs not fully discharged by the amount of the appealing party's bond shall be paid by the appealing party. Failure to timely pay said costs shall result in the appealing party being suspended from the city's vendor list until such payment is made.
The decision by the procurement appeals hearing officer under this section shall be final and binding on the city and shall thereafter represent the position of the city.
If a protest is upheld, the city, at its sole discretion, may do one (1) or more of the following:
Cancel the solicitation.
Award in part.
Re-compete the procurement.
In no event will a contract be automatically awarded to a protesting party if the protest is upheld.
Nothing herein shall prevent the city, at its sole discretion, from providing for an alternative remedy which is in the best interest of the city and in compliance with any applicable law.

Stay of contract award. In the event of a timely protest and/or appeal, the city will not proceed further with the award of the bid or proposal, unless the director of the soliciting department sets forth in writing particular facts and circumstances which require the continuance of the solicitation or contract award process without delay in order to avoid an immediate and serious danger to the public health, safety, or welfare.

Communication during pendency of solicitation. During any solicitation period, including any protest and/or appeal, no contact with city officers or employees, other than with the individuals specifically identified in the solicitation, the director of the soliciting department or the legal department, is permitted from any bidder or proposer. Such communication shall result in an automatic disqualification for selection in the pending solicitation and any subsequent city solicitations for a period of six (6) months, no matter the outcome of the solicitation or any protest and/or appeal.

Procurement appeals hearing officers. The city attorney, on behalf of the city, shall negotiate contracts with two (2) or more procurement appeals hearing officers who shall be assigned on a rotating basis in alphabetical order. If a procurement appeals hearing officer is unable to accept a case because of a conflict, time constraints, or any other reason, the case shall be assigned to the next procurement appeals hearing officer in said order. The officers shall possess the educational background and public or private employment experience to examine facts and apply legal principles, including, but not limited to experience with evidentiary and civil procedure issues, to controversies regarding procurement of goods and services, public improvement construction, professional and consultant services, and information technology in the municipal government sector. No city employee, city official, or anyone who owns any financial interest in any business entity which does business with the city shall be considered. Each officer shall hold hearings upon appeals of procurement protest decisions which shall be held in a municipal building and shall be open to the public. Administrative services, as may be required by the officers, shall be furnished by city departments. The procurement appeals hearing officer shall have the authority to review and determine any appeal by an aggrieved party from determination of a procurement protest by a review officer as authorized in this section.

Filing documents and computation of time. All dates, time frames and deadlines shall be calculated as city business days. A city business day shall mean 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. Monday through Friday, with the exception of city holidays. In all instances any document required to be transmitted by a certain date must be received in the required office by 4:30 p.m. Postmark by the required date in [is] not sufficient. Transmittal by fax, email or other electronic means may be accepted. However, it shall be the responsibility of the party transmitting the documents(s) to ensure that the document(s) were received, and the transmitting party shall bear any risk of an interruption or failure in the electronic transmission.

section.heading: Integrity of public contracting and purchasing; disqualification of certain persons and entities; etc.

para.text: In recognition that the preservation of the integrity of public contracting, purchasing and other transaction of the business of the city is vital and is a matter of great public interest, the council determines and declares that:

The procedures of the city for determining with whom the city transacts business exist to secure for the public the benefits of free, fair, and open competition among those persons or entities seeking to transact such business.
The opportunity to bid on public entity contracts or to supply goods and services to the city or to otherwise transact business with the city is a privilege, not a right.

In order to preserve the integrity of the public contracting and purchasing process, the privilege of transacting business with the city should be denied to persons involved in public entity crimes or certain other crimes or activities involving fraud, deceit or misrepresentation ("disqualifying activity"), with the allowance for waiver of same in exceptional circumstances and only after review and approval by the city council or public contract review board, established in the manner set forth herein.
It is the intent of this section to provide sufficient authority to the city, its departments and agencies, to ensure the integrity of public contracting and purchasing.

It is the further intent that any contract or business relationship with the city entered into in violation of this section shall not be void, but that the contract or business relationship be voidable pursuant to written notice by the city official with the authority to enter into such contract or business relationship or the mayor to the extent within the mayor's purview under the Charter of the city or the city council to the extent within its purview under the Charter of the city. The termination or voiding of any such contract or business relationship and the disqualification of any person or entity from doing business with the city shall be subject to review by the appellate body established hereunder, with such appellate body's determination subject to review by writ of certiorari to the Circuit Court in and for Hillsborough County, as and when provided below.
Unless the application of this section shall be waived by resolution or ordinance by city council, the city shall not enter into a contract or transact business:

With an individual who, personally or through an affiliated entity, as that term is defined herein, has been found to have engaged in disqualifying activity within the past five (5) years by a local, state or federal court or found to have committed, participated in or fostered any disqualifying activity as determined by a local, state or federal court or as determined pursuant to any administrative, regulatory, licensure or investigative process;
With an individual who has been indicated or against whom an information has been issued with respect to a "public entity crime";

With a corporation, partnership or other business entity ("disqualified entity") whose affairs and policies are legally or factually controlled by an individual (either directly or through intermediaries) who would be disqualified from doing business with the city under (b)(1) or (2) above ("disqualified person") or with any such entity providing consideration to such a disqualified person;

With a corporation, partnership or other business entity which is an affiliated entity of a disqualified entity or disqualified person. An affiliated entity, or the transferee of any person or business entity disqualified from doing business with the city under this subsection (b) or any subsequent transferee pursuant to a transfer, sale or assignment made in whole or in part for the purpose of avoiding the sanctions of this section shall be a disqualified entity hereunder.

In the awarding of any contract or grant, or in the providing of any guaranty of payment (whether by direct guaranty, promise to pay, administration of a grant or fund or assignment of a right to receive payment) or other action constituting the transaction of business with the city, the determination of the "lowest responsive responsible bidder" shall not simply be the lowest bidder, but also shall include but not be limited to the following factors:

The bidder's skill, judgment, experience, reputation for satisfactory work, financial soundness and other considerations relative to the quality of the goods or services to be provided, the terms of their delivery and the likelihood of any attendant expense and delay;
The conviction or findings of participation by any individual or affiliated entity in any crime, civil proceeding or activities described in subsection (b) above;

Any determination reflecting adversely on the integrity of such an individual or affiliated entity as may be evident from the issuance of any indictment, sanction, administrative determination, licensure, revocation or warning, regulatory action or civil proceeding related thereto;

Any other act or action, whether determined in a court, administrative proceeding, professional licensure hearing, investigation, or regulatory review which is determined to constitute a failure to meet any requirement of law, ordinance, rule or policy which otherwise reflects on the bidders compliance with applicable laws, rules, regulations and ordinances governing the conduct of its business;
Experience of delays, lack of coordination with any related work or service or poor performance on prior contracts with the city, which have been documented.

All officers or employees of the city awarding any contract or approving any payment or guaranty by the city, shall apply these "lowest responsive responsible bidder" criteria in a fair and legal manner and not arbitrarily or capriciously.

Any transfer of all or part of the ownership of an entity otherwise disqualified from public contracting, purchasing or transacting business with the city hereunder made at least in part for the purpose of avoiding or evading the requirements of subsections (b) and (c), shall be considered a sham transaction and shall result in a transferee being subject to the same requirements, limitations or provisions as would apply to the transferor hereunder. Any determination of disqualification from doing business with the city under this provision shall result in a written finding setting forth the basis therefor and shall be delivered to the party so disqualified. The notified party may contest the finding with the official or with the appellate body established herein. Such appeal shall be a hearing de novo.
As used in this section:

Affiliated entity means an entity under the control or subject to the ownership (whether legal, beneficial or equitable) or which provides compensation or other thing of value to any disqualified persons or disqualified entity. The term "affiliate" includes any entity which has any officer, director, executive, partner, shareholder, employee, member, or agent who is a disqualified person, who owns or benefits therefrom or is active in the management of that entity or receives consideration therefrom. The ownership by one (1) person of shares constituting a controlling interest in another person or entity, or a pooling of equipment or income among persons when not for fair market value under an arm's length agreement, shall be a prima facie case that one (1) person or entity controls another person or entity.

Business relationship shall mean the relationship, arrangement, agreement or contract established with the city for goods, work, services or products which the city either: (i) pays directly; (ii) guarantees payment; (iii) assigns the right to receive payment; or (iv) pays through or on behalf of another pursuant to a grant, fund or program administered by the city.
City means the City of Tampa and all its departments and agencies.

Convicted or conviction means a finding of guilt of a disqualifying activity, with or without final adjudication of guilt, in any federal, state or local court of record relating to charges brought by indictment or information as a result of a jury verdict, nonjury trial, or entry of a plea of guilty or nolo contendere.

Found or finding means a determination, finding of fact or conclusion of a fact finder, court, administrative body, licensing board or other regulatory agency, tribunal or organization pursuant to a process subject to reasonable safeguards intended to assure the accuracy thereof.

Owned or benefiting from means a twenty (20) percent or more ownership or the receipt of payments or other items of value whether received as employee, consultant, independent contractor or other relationship directly, or through an affiliated entity or related person.

Public entity crime means a violation of any city, state or federal law by a person with respect to and directly related to the transaction of business with any public entity or with an agency or political subdivision of any other state or with the United States, including, but not limited to, any bid or contract for goods or services, any lease for real property, or any contract for the construction or repair of a public building or public work or a contract which is paid or for which payment is made in whole or in part from public funds, involving antitrust, fraud, theft, bribery, collusion, racketeering, conspiracy, or material misrepresentation.

Transacting business means the entering into a contract with the city or any part thereof or entering into an agreement under which payments or the guaranty of payment is made by the city directly or to a third party who will make payment for such a contract whether from city funds or pursuant to the grant or other source of payment administered, reviewed, managed or approved by the city.

The city council or the public contract review board, if constituted as provided herein, shall overturn the improper application hereof, or otherwise repeal or waive any determination of disqualification made pursuant to the provisions of this section, if it is determined that there is very little risk to the free, fair and open competition to transact business with the city after considering all relevant factors including but not limited to:
The nature and details of the disqualifying activity.

Whether the disqualifying activity was committed by the individual, corporation, partnership or other entity seeking the contract or business relationship with the city, or by an individual in factual control or by a direct or an indirect owner or party benefited therefrom.
The degree of culpability of the individual, corporation, partnership or other business entity seeking the contract.
The promptness of the payment of any damages or penalty or other remedial action agreed upon or assessed in connection with the disqualifying activity.

The level of cooperation with any state, federal, regulatory or licensure investigation or prosecution at issue; provided that a good faith exercise of any constitutional, statutory, or other right during any portion of the investigation or prosecution of any crime shall not be considered a lack or cooperation.
The disassociation (or failure to disassociate) from any disqualified person or disqualified entity.
The commitment, if any, to self-policing or other curative measures to prevent any further disqualifying activity.
The reinstatement or grant of clemency by any jurisdiction, agency or authority in relation to any disqualifying activity.
The relationship of the disqualifying activity to the provision of work or procurement of goods and services sought.
The subsequent demonstration of good citizenship by the individual, corporation, partnership or other business entity seeking the contract.
The cost to the city or third party beneficiaries in voiding a contract or of refusing to waive the provisions.

The determination that any finding on which the exclusion from doing business with the city is based is not reliable, is no longer applicable (as in the case of the acquittal or dismissal of charges) or otherwise do not pose a sufficient concern to the integrity of the public contracting or procurement process.

Any decision so made shall be appealable by writ of certiorari filed with the Circuit Court in and for Hillsborough County within thirty (30) days after the delivery of any written determination by the city council or public contract review board.

A public contract review board may be set up to carry out the review, approval, waiver and appeal procedures of this section. If so, it shall be determined by the city council that it wishes to set up such a board rather than serving in that capacity itself. If the city council passes such an ordinance or resolution the board shall consist of three (3) members, two (2) of which shall be appointed by the mayor and the other by city council and all of whom shall be experienced in contract and procurement matters. The board so constituted shall conduct any such review, approval, waiver or appeal pursuant to the requirements set forth herein and shall provide a fair and open hearing of all matters brought before it including all relevant evidence. It shall meet as needed to review such matters to be brought before it and shall have procedures and policies for receiving information and evidence as other similar city boards and as appropriate to its task.
Except for the appellate rights provided herein, no party shall have standing to enforce this section in a court of competent jurisdiction except the city.

The director of the purchasing department or other city representative designated by the mayor shall maintain a list of disqualified persons or disqualified entities and provide same to other city agencies and departments for the purpose of complying with this section.

section.heading: Bidder's criminal history screening practices.
section.text: All competitive procurement methods utilized by the city shall contain a provision addressing whether the bidder has criminal history screening practices similar in nature to the practices contained in Chapter 12, Article VI, City of Tampa Code of Ordinances.

section.heading: Definitions.
section.text: For the purposes of this chapter, the following words are defined:

Disaster means the occurrence or imminent threat of widespread or severe damage, injury or loss of life or property resulting from any natural or man-made cause. These can include, but are not limited to, fire, flood, hurricane, wind, thunderstorm, tornado, hazardous material spill, epidemic, air contamination, critical material shortage, infestation, act of terrorism, cyber attack, explosion, radiological dispersion or other major incident requiring emergency action to avert danger or damage.
Emergency management means all those activities and measures undertaken by or on behalf of the city, designed:

para.text: To minimize the effect upon persons and property of natural or man-made disasters;
To deal with the immediate emergency conditions created by natural or man-made disasters; and
To effectuate emergency repairs to, or emergency restoration of, vital public utilities and facilities destroyed or damaged by natural or man-made disasters.

section.heading: Declaration of a state of local emergency; duration; alteration and rescission.

para.text: A state of local emergency shall be declared by executive order of the mayor if the mayor finds that an emergency, as defined in F.S. § 252.34, has occurred in the city or that the threat thereof is imminent. All executive orders issued under this article shall indicate the nature of the emergency, the area or areas threatened, and the conditions which have brought the emergency about or which make possible its termination. The executive order shall be promptly disseminated by means calculated to bring its contents to the attention of the general public; and, unless the circumstances attendant upon the emergency prevent or impede such filing, the order shall be filed promptly with the city clerk's office.
The duration of each state of local emergency declared is seven (7) days; it may be extended, as necessary, in seven (7) day increments by executive order.

Any state of local emergency declared may be altered during the continued or threatened existence of a state of local emergency, or rescinded, in the event that the emergency conditions cease to exist, by the issuance of a subsequent executive order(s).

In the event a state of local emergency declared pursuant to this section has been in effect continuously for more than thirty (30) days, and in the event a state or federal state of emergency is not also in effect, the mayor shall appear before city council at its next regular meeting to present the reasons for further continuance of the state of local emergency. If upon presentation of the mayor, the city council determines emergency conditions exist, the city council may extend the local state of emergency by resolution of the council. If upon presentation by the mayor, city council finds that emergency conditions no longer exist, city council may terminate the local state of emergency by resolution of the council. The mayor shall retain the authority to continue to extend any state of local emergency, pursuant to subsections 2-402(b) and (c), in seven-day increments in excess of thirty (30) days when:
A declared state or federal state of emergency continues to exist;
City council has not yet acted pursuant to this subsection (d);
City council has acted to extend the local state of emergency pursuant to this subsection (d).

section.heading: Emergency management powers of the mayor.
section.text: Upon declaration of a state of local emergency, the mayor, in addition to any other powers conferred upon the mayor by law, City of Tampa Charter or city ordinance, has the following power and authority:

para.text: To direct and compel the evacuation of all or part of the population from any stricken or threatened area within the city if he deems this action necessary for the preservation of life or other emergency mitigation, response, or recovery.
To waive the procedures and formalities otherwise required of the city by law or ordinance pertaining to:
Performance of public work and taking whatever prudent action is necessary to ensure the health, safety, and welfare of the community;
Entering into contracts;
Incurring obligations;
Employment of permanent and temporary workers;
Utilization of volunteer workers;
Rental of equipment;
Acquisition and distribution, with or without compensation, of supplies, materials, and facilities; and
Appropriation and expenditure of public funds.

Request emergency assistance and resources from higher levels of government, other local governments and/or other agencies, in accordance with the State of Florida Comprehensive Emergency Management Plan and/or the Statewide Mutual Aid Agreement and/or in accordance with the needs of the city and the resources available.

para.text: During the existence of a declared state of local emergency, the mayor may impose by executive order any or all of the following restrictions:

Prohibit or regulate the purchase, sale, transfer or possession of explosives, combustibles, dangerous weapons of any kind (except firearms which may be restricted by F.S. § 870.044), or alcoholic beverages;
Prohibit or regulate any special event, demonstration, parade, march, vigil or participation therein from taking place on any of the public rights-of-way or upon any public property;

Prohibit or regulate the sale or use of gasoline, kerosene, naphtha or any other explosive or flammable fluids or substances altogether, except by delivery into a tank properly affixed to an operable motor vehicle, bike, scooter, boat, or airplane and necessary for the propulsion thereof;

Prohibit or regulate the participation in or carrying on of any business activity, and prohibit or regulate the keeping open of places of business, places of entertainment and any other place of public assembly;

Prohibit or regulate travel upon any public street, highway or upon any other public property. Persons in search of medical assistance, food or other commodity or service necessary to sustain the well being of themselves or their families or some member thereof may be excepted from such prohibition or regulation;
A curfew upon all or any portion of the city thereby prohibiting persons from being on public streets, highways, parks or other public places during the hours which the curfew is in effect;

Prohibit state and/or local business licensees, vendors, merchants and any person operating a retail business from charging more than the normal average price for any goods, materials or services sold during a declared state of local emergency, except that the normal average price for any merchandise may be increased, but only to the degree that the maximum increase in retail price shall be a percentage less than or equal to the amount representative of the average mark-up percent between wholesale and average retail price for any merchandise during the thirty-day period immediately preceding the declared state of local emergency. The normal average price as used herein is defined to be that price at which similar merchandise, or services, has been sold during the thirty (30) days immediately preceding the declaration of a state of local emergency;
Prohibit any person, firm, or corporation from using the fresh water supplied by the city for any purpose other than cooking, drinking or bathing.

The executive order of the mayor may exempt, from all or part of such restrictions, physicians, nurses and ambulance operators performing medical services, on-duty employees of hospitals and other medical facilities, on-duty military personnel, bona fide members of the news media, personnel of public utilities maintaining essential public services, city authorized or requested firemen, law enforcement officers and personnel and such other classes of persons as may be essential to the preservation of public order and immediately necessary to serve safety, health and welfare needs of the people within the city.

section.heading: Emergency operations center.
section.text: The City of Tampa will maintain a hardened emergency operations center (herein "EOC") to provide standard local coordination and control of emergency, special event, or disaster response and relief operations for up to a twenty-four (24) hour-per-day basis, if necessary. The EOC will be equipped with the necessary computers, redundant communication devices, maps, displays, audio visual technology, status and situation boards, plans and procedures and will be supported by appropriate city emergency management personnel. The EOC will be managed by the director of emergency management and/or its emergency coordinator in accordance with the National Incident Management System. The EOC will be staffed with senior city officials and support organization representatives.

para.text: EOC staff will exercise appropriate authority over all emergency operations from or through the center in the event of a disaster or emergency including, declaring the onset and/or termination of a disaster or emergency.
The city's EOC will serve as the city's command center for executive leadership and direction and provide for the following:
To control and coordinate actions generated as result of orders from the executive policy group.
Provide direction and support to the disaster incident commander in the field.
Arrange for and deploy logistical resources that exceed the capabilities or purview of a single city department.

Initiate and coordinate recovery activities to meet the requirements that will follow the disaster and so that the public can receive all eligible assistance, allowing the city can return to a state of normalcy at the earliest time.
Coordinate and release disaster related public information.

section.heading: Continuity of operations; continuity of government.
section.text: The city shall maintain, through the Office of Emergency Management and Homeland Security, a viable continuity of operations plan that addresses the continuity of critical, essential and emergency functions performed by the City of Tampa to its citizens and visitors in the event of a natural or man-made disasters that diminishes, threatens or incapacitates one (1) or many departments of city government or the city government as a whole.

para.text: To maintain a viable COOP capability, each City of Tampa department's plan shall:
Be maintained at a high level of readiness.
Be capable of implementation both with and without warning.
Be operational no later than twelve (12) hours after activation.
Require that operations must be maintained for up to thirty (30) days.
Take maximum advantage of existing agency field infrastructures.
